The consolidation of a number
of the countries located on the Balkan Seas will be the subject of a
lecture to be given by C. Douglas
Booth before the International Relations Club T'uesday, October 20.
Mr. Booth, a traveler and publicist
of some note, is considered an authority on Balkan affairs. Much of
the political and economic information that he will present to the Hopkins audience was collected during
years of travel in the near east and
will eventually appear in book form.
A member of the Royal Institute
of International Affairs of Great
Britain, Mr. Booth submits fortnightly reports to that body on his
investigations. On a number of occasions, he has been called upon to
discuss international problems before the institute.
Enjoyed Varied Experience

The speaker is said to have enjoyed a varied lecttJring experience
including political work for the National Liberal Party of England,
~rid work in the United. States for
Liberty Loan and Red Cross drives
while with the allied forces during
the war. Later, he lectured in both
England and the United States on
international relations.
Mr. Booth was born in Canada
and was educated at St. Andrews
College, Toronto, and at Loyola
University. During the war he
held the rank of major in the English army. He has devoted seven
years to the study of Mediterranean
and Balkan problems, and has resided or travelled in Morocco,
Egypt, Rhodes, Patmos, Athens and
Belgrade. He has also spent some
time in study at the Academy of
International Law at The Hague.
Visited 50 Clubs

Two years ago, he visited more
than 50 of the International Relations Clubs in the colleges and universities of the South and the
Middle West under the auspices of
the Carnegie Endowment. While
in the United States, Mr. Booth will
lecture upon the following subjects:
The Permanent Court of International ] ustice.
2. The Austro-Hermanic Rapproachment as a Stabilizing
Factor in Middle Europe.
3. British Foreign Policy.
4. Balkan Consolidation-A Necessity to European Peace.
5. Remarks on Disarmament.
I.

Wrote Article For Institute

Among the articles Mr. Booth has
written is one on "The :Political
Situation in Southeastern Europe.''
This was presented before the Institute and published in the Journal
of the Royal Institute of International Affairs.
"Italy's Aegean
Possessions," published in 1928, is
also well known in the United
States, as are his articles written
for the American Peace Society of
Washington, D. C., and published
in "The Advocate of Peace.''
On Wednesday, October 21, Mr.
Booth will lecture to graduate students in Political Science on B.r itish
Foreign Policy.

C. DOUGLAS BOOTH

Musical Organization
Holds First Meeting
Because Of Large Attendance, Membership In Club Will Be Competitive; 85 Compose Group

The Johrts Hopkins Musical Club
held its initial rehearsal last Thursday night at Levering Hall. The
meeting of the Glee Club held at
7 :30 o'clock was followed by meetings of the Banjo Club and the
Hawaiian Troupe.
Due to the excessive turnout of
warblers, leader Steinwald explained that membership in the club
would be competitive. He declared
that a willing and faithful man is
more de~irable than just a good
voice. At present there are about
eighty-five members.
"Trees," a popular melody by
Joyce Kilmer, was chosen for the
first number. The other numbers
will be chosen by Mr. Steinwald
according to the ability of the songsters.
Ronald Levy, president of the
Glee Club, asked for regular and
early attendance and a serious outlook on the activities of the Club.

Well Known Author
Will Speak Tonight
"National Defense: What Kind?"
h To Be Kirby Page's Topic
At Supper. Club

The well-known author and
pacifist, Kirby Page, will be the
speaker at the first meeting of the
University Supper Club this evening at 6 :30 o'clock.
The speaker will be introduced
by Dean Edward W. Berry and
will have as his subject "National
Defense: What Kind." Officials of
the R. 0. T. C. here have been invited to the meeting to answer any
charges brought against that organization by Mr. Page.

Dr. John R. Oliver, former state
psychiatrist and Harvard graduate
lectured Thursday to the first class
in Medical Ethics and The History
of Medicine in Remsen 22r. Dr:
Oliver, in his lecture attempted to
familiarize the group with some of
the best titles of works on the history of medicine.
"In order that a physician may
truly appreciate the value of his
profession, it is essential that he
have a knowledge of the history of
that profession," said the former
pupil of the late Sir William Osler.
Must Keep Confidence

Dr. Oliver pointed out that a
physician should have contact with
the past and the future as well as
the present. He stressed the necessity of the physician's holding confident the information given him by
his patients.
"A physician," he said, "is given
privileged information; he is told
things by his patient that would be
told to no other living soul except
that patient's priest . . A man. will
lie to his friends, to his associates,
even to his wife; but he will not lie
to his doctor, and the doctor must
respect this privilege."
Dr. Oliver emphasized the inevitability of routine and·the necessity
for hard work. He quoted a lecture given by Sir William Osler, in
which that eminent physician said,
"The master word in medicine is a
four letter word-'W ork.' "
Should Remain In Ethics

When Miss Fanny Pentz kicked
the bucket on August 12 leaving
$82,900 to numerous charitable
agencies and the residue of her estate to the Johns Hopkins, her will
revealed that she was a bit perturbed lest God and the State of
Maryland be left out in the cold.
Since she had no remaining funds
to bequeath and since, in consideration of Fanny's mortal state, the
Former Gentleman obviously ought
to be propitiated somehow, the
spinster was in some kind of a fix.
But she solved the problem neatly.
She deposited her soul with God
and as an after thought consigned
her body to the land of the Free
State.
Reads her will :
"I, Fanny Pentz, of Baltimore
City in the State of Maryland, do
hereby make and publish this, my
last will and testament, in the manner and form following, that is to
say:
Commits Soul To God

"First and principally: I commit
my soul to God, who gave it, and
my body to the earth whence it
came to be decently interred, and

Dr. Edward Park's Secretary
After Guarding Him Valiantly From Interview
With Inquisitive Visitor
Dr. Edward Park rides to his
office every morning on a bicycle.
At night he again climbs on the
saddle and peddles away to his
home harum, scarum-come what
may. Between bicycle rides, he
teaches and practices medicine at
the Johns Hopkins Hospital andif his secretary is to be believedis a very, very busy man.
This information is the result of
a call made by a visitor to the professor's office that serves as a depot
for so much bicycle riding.

"What about," was the businesslike reply. "I'm his secretary."
"I want to speak to Dr. Park,
personally."
"Well, I'm Dr. Park's personal
secretary," she countered.
"I want to speak to Dr. Park
personally on account of I want to
speak confidentially."

But apparently Fanny Pentz was
not particularly sanguine that God
would be satisfied with so little to
remember her by as her soul. So
she bequeathed over $45,000 to
every sort of religious organization
imaginable.
Feared The Ash-Can?

There seems, moreover, to be
some question as to what Fanny
Pentz meant on reque~ting to be
"decently interred." Could it be
possible that she feared that in the
rush to settle S'UCh a magnificent estate, her earthly remains wouid be
carelessly tossed into an ash-can or
something?
But wherever the
spinter's body rests, it is well
marked; for Fanny's w111 provides
for a suitable monument costing not
one penny less than $1 ,ooo.
The death of one of the two executors has delayed the settling of
the estate. The other executor is
not anxious to serve and is looking
around for someone to pinch-hit for
h;m. After all, who wants to undertake the delicate business of delivering Fanny's soul into the hand's

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., TUESDAY, OCTOBER 13, 1931

'Main Street' Proves Attraction
PH.D. LANGUAGE EXAM
To Johns Hopkins Archaeologist CHANGES ANNOUNDED
Dr. David M. Robinson Plans To Continue Excavations
At Olynthus, Greece, To Find End
of Thoroughfare

-r--

Although the excavation work of
his last expedition to Olynthus,
Greece, was more productive than
any of his previous expeditions, Dr.
David M. Robinson, W. H. Collins
Vickers, Professor of Archaeology
and Epigraphy, plans to make several more trips to Greece. According to a recent announcement he
expects to uncover much more of
what he terms the first classical city
to be excavated with whole blocks
of private houses, filled with art objects of the first importance.
The mystery of the "Main Street"
of this ancient Hellenic city, destroyed in 348 B. C. by Phillip of
Macedon, father of Alexander the
Great, has especially attracted the
Hopkins man's interest. He wants
to continue his excavations of this
antique thoroughfare, because he
feels certain that it led to the public
square of this city. Here he expects
to uncover material which may
radically change certain chapters of
Greek history.
Olynthus Was Capital
For Olynthus was the capital of
the Chalcidic League, a group of
important cities, and it is possible,
Di-. Robinson states, that he may
find the constitution of the League
inscribed upon some monument.
This expedition, which was the
third the Hopkins savant had made
to Olynthus, was in progress from
March 25th to June r 8th. 400
Christian i;efogees, who live near
the site in a town which they, in
honor of Dr. Robinson, have renamed New Olynthus, were pired
to do the labor.
At times, according to Dr. Robinson;the weekly payroll amounted to
75,000 drachmas, or about $r,ooo,
although the workmen received only
4oc a day. Every shovel-full of
dirt was carefully examined by the
archaeologist and his staff of assistants.
Over 27 Houses Uncovered
Over 27 houses were uncovered
on the North Hill of the city in addition to many shops on the South
Hill.
The discovery of many
streets, led to the drawing up of a
plan of the city.
In these houses, the excavators

Find Coins Also
A large number of terra-cotta
masks and figurenes were also uncovered, as well as several hordes
of coins. These coins are irnportant for their historical and commercial significance, as well as for
their artistic excellence. Out of the
1222 coins found, less than 25 are
after the time of Phillip.
Dr. Robinson is writing up his
discoveries and is having colored
reµroductions made of those objects
which he will not be able to bring
to this country to illustrate his book.
He has already had several books
published on his previous work at
Olynthus.

homes, according to Dr. Robinson,
destroys the theory that the Greeks
until the Hellenistic Age lived in

Two Cemeteries Discovered
Two cemeteries were discovered
also, and nearly 200 graves were
opened by the party, who thus determined that both inhumation and
cremation were practiced.
Many vases were found in these
cemeteries, full of bones which Dr.
Robinson offers as clinching proof
of bis theory that vases in ancient
Greece were used for burial urns
as well as ornaments. This was the
first time that this unusual type of
interrement has been found, he explained.

now and then, does not mean

Plana To

Last Year's Program,

Within the nex t month definite
plans will have been decided upon
for the fraternity rushing period
following the mid-year exams, it
was stated by Walter Kneip, president of the Interfraternity Board.
The Board has had the first two of
its weekly meetings and will devote
its time to the determining of the
limits and regulations governing
rushing week.
As much as may be stated at
present is that the program adopted
will be very similar to the one used
last season, with possibility of
minor changes. The principal fact
concerning pledging of freshmen is
that none are to be pledged until
the mid-year exams have been finished. Special days for entertaining are assigned to each fraternity
represented on the Board.
The Board is 'made up of two
members from each of the fraternities represented thereon. Each
fraternity in the group is bound to
observe the regulations adopted by
the Board.

The consolidation of a number
of the countries located on the Balkan Seas will be the subject of a
lecture to be given by C. Douglas
Booth before the International Relations Club T'uesday, October 20.
Mr. Booth, a traveler and publicist
of some note, is considered an authority on Balkan affairs. Much of
the political and economic information that he will present to the Hopkins audience was collected during
years of travel in the near east and
will eventually appear in book form.
A member of the Royal Institute
of International Affairs of Great
Britain, Mr. Booth submits fortnightly reports to that body on his
investigations. On a number of occasions, he has been called upon to
discuss international problems before the institute.
Enjoyed Varied Experience

The speaker is said to have enjoyed a varied lecttJring experience
including political work for the National Liberal Party of England,
~rid work in the United. States for
Liberty Loan and Red Cross drives
while with the allied forces during
the war. Later, he lectured in both
England and the United States on
international relations.
Mr. Booth was born in Canada
and was educated at St. Andrews
College, Toronto, and at Loyola
University. During the war he
held the rank of major in the English army. He has devoted seven
years to the study of Mediterranean
and Balkan problems, and has resided or travelled in Morocco,
Egypt, Rhodes, Patmos, Athens and
Belgrade. He has also spent some
time in study at the Academy of
International Law at The Hague.
Visited 50 Clubs

Two years ago, he visited more
than 50 of the International Relations Clubs in the colleges and universities of the South and the
Middle West under the auspices of
the Carnegie Endowment. While
in the United States, Mr. Booth will
lecture upon the following subjects:
The Permanent Court of International ] ustice.
2. The Austro-Hermanic Rapproachment as a Stabilizing
Factor in Middle Europe.
3. British Foreign Policy.
4. Balkan Consolidation-A Necessity to European Peace.
5. Remarks on Disarmament.
I.

Wrote Article For Institute

Among the articles Mr. Booth has
written is one on "The :Political
Situation in Southeastern Europe.''
This was presented before the Institute and published in the Journal
of the Royal Institute of International Affairs.
"Italy's Aegean
Possessions," published in 1928, is
also well known in the United
States, as are his articles written
for the American Peace Society of
Washington, D. C., and published
in "The Advocate of Peace.''
On Wednesday, October 21, Mr.
Booth will lecture to graduate students in Political Science on B.r itish
Foreign Policy.

C. DOUGLAS BOOTH

Musical Organization
Holds First Meeting
Because Of Large Attendance, Membership In Club Will Be Competitive; 85 Compose Group

The Johrts Hopkins Musical Club
held its initial rehearsal last Thursday night at Levering Hall. The
meeting of the Glee Club held at
7 :30 o'clock was followed by meetings of the Banjo Club and the
Hawaiian Troupe.
Due to the excessive turnout of
warblers, leader Steinwald explained that membership in the club
would be competitive. He declared
that a willing and faithful man is
more de~irable than just a good
voice. At present there are about
eighty-five members.
"Trees," a popular melody by
Joyce Kilmer, was chosen for the
first number. The other numbers
will be chosen by Mr. Steinwald
according to the ability of the songsters.
Ronald Levy, president of the
Glee Club, asked for regular and
early attendance and a serious outlook on the activities of the Club.

Well Known Author
Will Speak Tonight
"National Defense: What Kind?"
h To Be Kirby Page's Topic
At Supper. Club

The well-known author and
pacifist, Kirby Page, will be the
speaker at the first meeting of the
University Supper Club this evening at 6 :30 o'clock.
The speaker will be introduced
by Dean Edward W. Berry and
will have as his subject "National
Defense: What Kind." Officials of
the R. 0. T. C. here have been invited to the meeting to answer any
charges brought against that organization by Mr. Page.

Dr. John R. Oliver, former state
psychiatrist and Harvard graduate
lectured Thursday to the first class
in Medical Ethics and The History
of Medicine in Remsen 22r. Dr:
Oliver, in his lecture attempted to
familiarize the group with some of
the best titles of works on the history of medicine.
"In order that a physician may
truly appreciate the value of his
profession, it is essential that he
have a knowledge of the history of
that profession," said the former
pupil of the late Sir William Osler.
Must Keep Confidence

Dr. Oliver pointed out that a
physician should have contact with
the past and the future as well as
the present. He stressed the necessity of the physician's holding confident the information given him by
his patients.
"A physician," he said, "is given
privileged information; he is told
things by his patient that would be
told to no other living soul except
that patient's priest . . A man. will
lie to his friends, to his associates,
even to his wife; but he will not lie
to his doctor, and the doctor must
respect this privilege."
Dr. Oliver emphasized the inevitability of routine and·the necessity
for hard work. He quoted a lecture given by Sir William Osler, in
which that eminent physician said,
"The master word in medicine is a
four letter word-'W ork.' "
Should Remain In Ethics

the bucket on August 12 leaving

agencies and the residue of her estate to the Johns Hopkins, her will
revealed that she was a bit perturbed lest God and the State of
Maryland be left out in the cold.

and as an after thought consigned
her body to the land of the Free
State.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., TUESDAY, OCTOBER 13, 1931

'Main Street' Proves Attraction
PH.D. LANGUAGE EXAM
To Johns Hopkins Archaeologist CHANGES ANNOUNDED
Dr. David M. Robinson Plans To Continue Excavations
At Olynthus, Greece, To Find End
of Thoroughfare

-r--

Although the excavation work of
his last expedition to Olynthus,
Greece, was more productive than
any of his previous expeditions, Dr.
David M. Robinson, W. H. Collins
Vickers, Professor of Archaeology
and Epigraphy, plans to make several more trips to Greece. According to a recent announcement he
expects to uncover much more of
what he terms the first classical city
to be excavated with whole blocks
of private houses, filled with art objects of the first importance.
The mystery of the "Main Street"
of this ancient Hellenic city, destroyed in 348 B. C. by Phillip of
Macedon, father of Alexander the
Great, has especially attracted the
Hopkins man's interest. He wants
to continue his excavations of this
antique thoroughfare, because he
feels certain that it led to the public
square of this city. Here he expects
to uncover material which may
radically change certain chapters of
Greek history.
Olynthus Was Capital
For Olynthus was the capital of
the Chalcidic League, a group of
important cities, and it is possible,
Di-. Robinson states, that he may
find the constitution of the League
inscribed upon some monument.
This expedition, which was the
third the Hopkins savant had made
to Olynthus, was in progress from
March 25th to June r 8th. 400
Christian i;efogees, who live near
the site in a town which they, in
honor of Dr. Robinson, have renamed New Olynthus, were pired
to do the labor.
At times, according to Dr. Robinson;the weekly payroll amounted to
75,000 drachmas, or about $r,ooo,
although the workmen received only
4oc a day. Every shovel-full of
dirt was carefully examined by the
archaeologist and his staff of assistants.
Over 27 Houses Uncovered
Over 27 houses were uncovered
on the North Hill of the city in addition to many shops on the South
Hill.
The discovery of many
streets, led to the drawing up of a
plan of the city.
In these houses, the excavators

Find Coins Also
A large number of terra-cotta
masks and figurenes were also uncovered, as well as several hordes
of coins. These coins are irnportant for their historical and commercial significance, as well as for
their artistic excellence. Out of the
1222 coins found, less than 25 are
after the time of Phillip.
Dr. Robinson is writing up his
discoveries and is having colored
reµroductions made of those objects
which he will not be able to bring
to this country to illustrate his book.
He has already had several books
published on his previous work at
Olynthus.

The finding of these luxurious
homes, according to Dr. Robinson,
destroys the theory that the Greeks
until the Hellenistic Age lived in
petty little towns and houses.
Two Cemeteries Discovered
Two cemeteries were discovered
also, and nearly 200 graves were
opened by the party, who thus determined that both inhumation and
cremation were practiced.
Many vases were found in these
cemeteries, full of bones which Dr.
Robinson offers as clinching proof
of bis theory that vases in ancient
Greece were used for burial urns
as well as ornaments. This was the
first time that this unusual type of
interrement has been found, he explained.

look at the team itself. A man

\Vhat can a major letter mean to

now and then, does not mean
that the men aren't trying.

Decide Rushing Rules
Plana To

Be Much

The

Same As

Last Year's Program,
Expected

Within the nex t month definite
plans will have been decided upon
for the fraternity rushing period
following the mid-year exams, it
was stated by Walter Kneip, president of the Interfraternity Board.
The Board has had the first two of
its weekly meetings and will devote
its time to the determining of the
limits and regulations governing
rushing week.
As much as may be stated at
present is that the program adopted
will be very similar to the one used
last season, with possibility of
minor changes. The principal fact
concerning pledging of freshmen is
that none are to be pledged until
the mid-year exams have been finished. Special days for entertaining are assigned to each fraternity
represented on the Board.
The Board is 'made up of two
members from each of the fraternities represented thereon. Each
fraternity in the group is bound to
observe the regulations adopted by
the Board.
